pageData.text: The combination of Newton’s laws of motion and <button class='glossary-text'>Newton’s law of universal gravitation</button> form the foundation of <button class='glossary-text'>classical mechanics</button>, which explains the motion of ordinary physical objects under everyday conditions. <button class='glossary-text'>Newton’s first law of motion</button>, or the <button class='glossary-text'>law of inertia</button>, states an object at rest remains at rest and an object in motion remains in motion at constant speed unless acted on by an unbalanced <button class='glossary-text'>force</button>. <button class='glossary-text'>Newton’s second law of motion</button> states that net force is equal to mass times <button class='glossary-text'>acceleration</button>. <button class='glossary-text'>Newton’s third law of motion</button> states for every action force there is an equal and opposite reaction force. In this investigation, you will explore Newton’s three laws of motion, giving you a better understanding of objects in motion.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 15 minutes 
Activity 1: Exploring Newton’s Laws of Motion
                 First Demonstration of Newton’s First Law of Motion – 20 minutes 
                 Second Demonstration of Newton’s First Law of Motion – 25 minutes
Activity 2: Verifying Newton’s Second Law of Motion
                 First Angle – 15 minutes
                 Second Angle – 10 minutes
                 Third Angle – 10 minutes
                 Data Analysis – 20 minutes
Extension Activity 1: Newton’s Laws of Motion Demonstrated Using a Balloon Rocket – 40 minutes

Calculate the <button class='glossary-text'>acceleration</button> of an object moving up an incline.
Verify <button class='glossary-text'>Newton’s second law of motion</button>.

pageData.text: The fastest figure skater in the world is Canada’s Olivia Oliver. In 2015, Oliver achieved the current Guinness record for the fastest spin, 342 rotations per minute (RPM). The record for most continuous upright spins on ice skates on one foot is 115, held by Switzerland’s Lucinda Ruh<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>. Top skaters generally are able to complete as many as six revolutions per second. How is it possible for skaters to spin so fast, for so long, and not get dizzy?

The smooth ice allows for skates to move across the ice with very little friction (Newton's first law). When a spinning figure skater brings in their arms, the distance from their spin center is smaller, so their speed increases. When their arms are out, the distance from the spin center is greater, so the spin slows down (law of conservation of angular <button class='glossary-text'>momentum</button>). According to Mirai Nagasu, an American ice figure skater, skaters don’t get dizzy because “we have a learned ability against the momentum that hits us while we’re spinning.”<sup class='bodySupscript'>2</sup>
1Guinness World Records (2023). https://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/

2Karimi, F. (2022). Why Olympic figure skaters don’t get dizzy. CNN.
https://www.cnn.com/2022/02/16/sport/olympics-figure-skating-questions-cec/index.html

pageData.altText: A woman performing a spin on ice with one foot, the leg fully extended. The opposite leg and upper body are perpendicular to the planted leg.

pageData.subTitle: Newton’s Laws of Motion
pageData.text: , also referred to as Newtonian mechanics, is the area of physics built on the works of Sir Isaac Newton (1643–1727), comprising Newton’s three laws of motion and . Newton’s laws of motion are given designations to aid in recalling them: is the , is F = ma, and is action − reaction. The core of classical mechanics is the combination of these mathematical laws and principles: Newton’s first law of motion, Newton’s second law of motion, Newton’s third law of motion, Newton’s law of universal gravitation, , , and .

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Sir Isaac Newton

pageData.text: Newton’s first law of motion states that an object at rest will remain at rest or in uniform motion in a straight line unless acted upon by a net external <button class='glossary-text'>force</button>. This statement describes <button class='glossary-text'>inertia</button>, the tendency of an object to resist changes in motion; mass SI unit of kilogram [kg] is the quantitative measure of inertia. The International Committee for Weights and Measures has defined the kilogram by defining Planck’s constant to be exactly 6.62607015×10<sup class='bodySupscript'>-34</sup> kg•m<sup class='bodySupscript'>2</sup>•s<sup class='bodySupscript'>-1</sup>, effectively defining the kilogram in terms of the second and the meter.
is the mathematical relationship between , mass, and or between force and the derivative with respect to time of as shown in Equation 1.

pageData.altText: Equation 1: Epsilon F equals ma or F equals begin fraction dp over dt end fraction

pageData.text: Force, F, is a vector with SI units of newtons [N = kg m/s2], and acceleration, a, is also a vector quantity with SI units of m/s2. Momentum, p, is equal to mass times velocity and is a vector with SI units of kg m/s. The force is the net external force and is applicable to a wide range of physical phenomena, but it is not a fundamental principle like the conservation laws. When the net force is defined as the rate of change of momentum, the relationship net force equals mass times acceleration will only apply if the mass is constant. A change in the acceleration of an object with a fixed mass will result in a corresponding change in the net force, such as when the acceleration of an object increases and the mass remains constant, the acceleration change was caused by an increase in the net force.

<button class='glossary-text'>Newton's third law of motion</button> states for every action there is an equal and opposite reaction; this means all forces in the universe occur in equal but oppositely directed pairs. For every external force acting on an object, there is a force with an equal magnitude in the opposite direction acting back on the object; these forces do not cancel because the action force and the reaction force act on different objects.

describes the pull of gravity between two objects as being proportional to the masses of the objects, m1 and m2, and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between the masses, r, as shown in Equation 2.

pageData.altText: Equation 2: F equals begin fraction G m sub 1 m sub 2 over r sub 2 end fraction where G equals 6.67 times 10 sup minus sign 11 begin fraction m sup 3 over kg s sup 2 end fraction

pageData.question: What law states that an object at rest will remain at rest or an object in motion will remain in motion unless an unbalanced force acts upon it?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Newton’s first law of motion states that an object at rest will remain at rest or in uniform motion in a straight line unless acted upon by a net external force.

pageData.question: How can you tell if a moving object is experiencing an unbalanced force?

options.text: It is speeding up, slowing down, or changing direction.
It is moving at a constant velocity.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A net force can be quantified by the product of mass and acceleration.  Recall that acceleration is a vector quantity, so it has magnitude and direction.   Any change in speed of the object OR the direction of motion will result in a change in the acceleration which indicates an unbalanced force.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Newton’s laws of motion are given designations to aid in recalling them: Newton’s first law of motion is the law of inertia, Newton’s second law of motion is F = ma, and Newton’s third law of motion is action − reaction. The core of classical mechanics is the combination of these mathematical laws and principles: Newton’s first law of motion, Newton’s second law of motion, Newton’s third law of motion, Newton’s law of universal gravitation, law of conservation of energy, law of conservation of momentum, and Bernoulli’s principle.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Newton’s laws of motion are given designations to aid in recalling them: Newton’s first law of motion is the law of inertia, Newton’s second law of motion is F = ma, and Newton’s third law of motion is action − reaction. The core of classical mechanics is the combination of these mathematical laws and principles: Newton’s first law of motion, Newton’s second law of motion, Newton’s third law of motion, Newton’s law of universal gravitation, law of conservation of energy, law of conservation of momentum, and Bernoulli’s principle.

pageData.subTitle: The Law of Conservation of Energy
pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>law of conservation of energy</button> states energy cannot be created nor destroyed; it is transformed from one type to another. For example, when a hydroelectric dam transforms the kinetic energy of water into electrical energy, when energy is transferred or transformed, the total amount of energy does not change (Figure 2).

pageData.altText: Figure 2: A hydroelectric dam with water rushing from the top of the dam to the bottom.

pageData.subTitle: <span style='padding-bottom:5px;display:block;'>The Law of Conservation of Momentum
pageData.text: The states for an isolated system, where there is no external , the total before an event such as a collision is equal to the total momentum after the event. Equation 3 is the mathematical expression for the conservation of momentum, where momentum, p = mv.

pageData.altText: Equation 3: Epsilon p sub before equals epsilon p sub after

pageData.subTitle: Bernoulli’s Principle
pageData.text: is a statement of conservation of energy for fluid flow. The total energy per unit mass of flowing fluid is the sum of the kinetic, potential, and fluid-pressure energies and their sum is equal to a constant. Bernoulli's Principle is stated mathematically in Equation 4.

pageData.altText: Equation 4: P sub 1 plus begin fraction 1 over 2 end fraction rho v sup 2 sub 1 plus rho g h sub 1 equals P sub 2 plus begin fraction 1 over 2 end fraction rho v sup 2 sub 2 plus rho g h sub 2

pageData.text: where P1 and P2 measure absolute pressure, which is equal to atmospheric pressure plus gauge pressure; fluid density is ρ [kg/m3]; fluid velocity is v [m/s]; g is the due to gravity, 9.80 m/s2; and the depth of the fluid is h [m].

The combination of these laws and principles provides the foundation for explaining the motion of ordinary physical objects under normal conditions but not to situations when speeds are extremely high or objects are incredibly small. The inconsistencies resulting from the extremes speeds were remedied by Einstein's Special Theory of Relativity and were resolved for incredibly small objects by quantum mechanics.

pageData.subTitle: Newton’s Second Law Problem—Mass on an Incline Plane with a Pulley
pageData.text: Newton’s second law can be applied to many situations to determine the of objects; an example is a two-mass system on an incline as shown in Figure 3. The first mass, m1, is placed on a frictionless incline of angle θ, and is attached to a hanging mass, m2, by a cord over a frictionless pulley. The hanging mass creates tension in the cord, which is used to accelerate the mass, m1, up the incline. Newton’s second law can then be used to determine the acceleration of the mass moving up the incline plane. Drawing will help visualize the acting on the masses. The free body diagrams are also shown in Figure 3.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Free body diagram showing a mass on an incline with a pulley

pageData.text: The acceleration of the system of masses, mass m1 and mass m2, is a single value that is calculated by applying Newton’s second law to each mass. The following steps show how the formula for the acceleration is determined.
Tension in the cord is T, N is the normal , and g is the due to gravity, 9.80 m/s2.
Newton’s second law for mass, m1, using the forces along or parallel to the incline as shown in , the direction of positive acceleration is up the incline.

pageData.altText: Epsilon f sub parallel equals m sub 1 a equals t minus m sub 1 g sine theta

pageData.text: Solve for T = m1a + m1gsinθ
Newton’s second law for mass, m2, as shown in Figure 3, the direction of positive acceleration is down.

pageData.altText: Epsilon f sub hanging mass equals m sub 2 a equals m sub 2 g minus t

pageData.text: Solve for T:T = m2g − m2a
Set the expressions for tension, T, equal as the tension in the cord is the same everywhere along the length of the cord.
m1a + m1gsinθ = m2g − m2a
Solve for a:m1a + m2a = m2g − m1gsinθ

pageData.altText: Equation 5: a equals begin fraction g begin paren m sub 2 minus sign m sub 1 sine theta end paren over begin paren m sub 1 plus m sub 2 end paren end fraction

pageData.text: The acceleration of the system can be calculated using Equation 5 when the angle of the incline and the masses, m1 and m2, are known. The system shown in will be used in the Newton’s laws of motion activities to investigate force and acceleration as well as verify .

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow of activities 1-2 of the investigation. In activity 1, set up an index card, beaker and coin and record the removal of the index card and fall of the coin. Next, add another coin and repeat. Then, fill a beaker, place it on a paper at the edge of a table and record the removal of the paper. Then, repeat with an empty beaker.  In activity 2, set up the ramp and pulley and calculate its angle and dimensions. Then, set up the beaker with string and attach it to the pulley. Next, measure the mass of the beaker and washers. Then, attach washers to the hanger. Next, add washers to the beaker until it is moving with an acceleration of ~2 m/s2. Then, measure the total mass of the washers in the beaker and repeat for 3 trials. Next, modify the angle of the ramp and repeat for 3 angles. Then, calculate the acceleration for each trial, the average acceleration and the standard deviation. Finally, analyze the data for a standard distribution. Proceed to the extension activity.

A map of the procedural workflow of the extension activity of this investigation. After completing activity 2, in the extension activity, you will fully inflate a balloon and attach a straw to it. Then, you will set up the string, balloon apparatus and chairs. Next, you will measure the circumference of the inflated balloon. Then, you will record the release and flight of the balloon along the sting and measure the distance of the flight. When you have completed 3 trials for the fully inflated balloon, you will then inflate the balloon half-full and attach a straw to it. Then, you will set up the string, balloon apparatus and chairs. Next, you will measure the circumference of the inflated balloon. Then, you will record the release and flight of the balloon along the sting and measure the distance of the flight. Finally, you will repeat this for 3 trials.

Wear your safety goggles at all times while conducting this investigation. Read all the instructions for this activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment

pageData.altText: goggles symbol

pageData.text: Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this investigation. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after the investigation and clean the work area with soap and water after finishing. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.subTitle: Alternate Methods for Collecting Data Using Digital Devices
pageData.text: Much of the uncertainty in physics experiments arises from human reaction time error in measuring the times of events. Some of the time intervals are very short, which increases the effect of human error due to reaction time. Observing the experiment from a good vantage point that removes parallax errors and recording measurements for multiple trials helps to minimize error; using a digital device as an alternate method of data collection may further minimize error. Many digital devices, such as smartphones and tablets, have cameras and software that allow the user to pause or slow down the video. If you film the activity against a scale such as a tape measure, you can use your video playback program to record position and time data. This can provide more accurate data and may eliminate the need for multiple trials. If the time on your device’s playback program is not sufficiently accurate, you may download an app such as the following free apps:

• OnForm
    iOS and Android (https://www.getonform.com/)
  • SloPro
    iOS (https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/slopro1000fps-slow-motion/id507232505?mt=8)
    Android (https://slopro.en.uptodown.com/android)
Or you may upload the video to your computer. Your operating system or software suite may include video playback programs, or these programs may be available for download.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: If an unbalanced force acts on an object initially at rest, the object will_________.

options.text: accelerate in the same direction as the unbalanced force
acceleration in the opposite direction as the unbalanced force
move at a constant velocity in the same direction as the unbalanced force
move at a constant velocity in the opposite direction as the unbalanced force

assestmentData.question: You are traveling in a car that is moving forward when the driver suddenly slams on the brake.  What happens to you?

options.text: You stopped moving because the brakes were applied.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following statements describes net force?

options.text: It is the sum of all the forces acting on an object.
It is the force associated with the Internet.
It is the result of the acceleration due to gravity.
It is the quantitative measure of inertia.
It is the same as the normal force.

assestmentData.question: According to Newton’s Third Law, what happens when you push against the wall?

options.text: The wall pushes you with the same magnitude of force as your push on the wall but in the opposite direction.
The wall pushes you with the same magnitude of force as your push on the wall in the same direction.
The wall does not exert any force.
The wall pushes you with twice the amount of force exerted by you.
The wall pushes you with half the force exerted by you.

assestmentData.question: Which of Newton’s laws describes force as the rate of change of momentum?

options.text: None of Newton’s laws describe momentum.

assestmentData.question: The amount of force needed to move an object is measured in which of the following units?
Which object has the greatest inertia?

options.text: a ping pong ball in motion
a ping pong ball at rest

assestmentData.question: A falling object is pulled down by Earth. Earth is pulled up toward the object. Why does the Earth not move?

options.text: Earth has a very large mass and a very small acceleration.
Earth has a very small mass and a very large acceleration.
Air resistance prevents Earth from accelerating.
Gravitational forces only act upon small objects.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the procedure.
Gather the needed materials for this investigation. An alternative to using the foamboard is a table or desk item as the incline plane.
Clear the work area (table or desk) completely.

In Activity 1, you will explore <button class='glossary-text'>Newton’s first and second laws of motion</button> by observing what happens when you remove a card from under the coin balancing on it and when you remove a sheet of paper from under a full and an empty beaker of water.

typeBefore.title:
A
 First Demonstration of Newton’s First Law of Motion (5 steps)

pageData.text: Set the plastic beaker on a table or desk. Place the index card over the opening of the beaker. Set one coin on top of and in the center of the index card.
Set up the digital camera or mobile device to record a video of the beaker setup. It may be helpful to have a volunteer hold the recording device.

Start recording a video. Try to drop the coin into the beaker without touching the coin. Use your finger and thumb to flick the index card out from under the coin and observe what happens. Then stop the recording.
pageData.altText: Record a video

pageData.text: Flicking the index card may take some practice. Repeat Steps 1–3 as needed until the coin drops into the beaker.
Try placing multiple coins at the center of the index card on the beaker. Then repeat Steps 2–3.

typeBefore.title:
B
 Second Demonstration of Newton’s First Law of Motion (7 steps)

typeBefore.text: Important safety note: This activity involves water that may spill. Select a work area where spilled water will not cause any damage.

pageData.text: Place a sheet of paper on the edge of the table so approximately one third of the length of the paper hangs over the edge.
Fill the beaker halfway with water. Place the beaker at the center of the portion of the paper remaining on the table.
Set up the digital camera or mobile device to record a video of the beaker setup. It may be helpful to have a volunteer hold the recording device.

Start recording a video. Remove the paper from under the beaker without touching the beaker. Hold the paper where it hangs over the edge of the table and quickly jerk down on the paper. Stop the recording.
pageData.altText: Record a video

pageData.text: Removing the paper may take some practice. Repeat Steps 1–4 as needed until the paper can be removed without tipping over the beaker.
Try setting up the activity with an empty beaker. Repeat Steps 3 and 4.
Empty the beaker and dry it out using a paper or dish towel before starting Activity 2.

In Activity 2, you will attach a beaker to a ramp and pulley system and add weights to the system to get the beaker to move at a constant <button class='glossary-text'>acceleration</button>. You will then vary the angle of the ramp and determine the effect it has on the mass needed to move the beaker at a constant acceleration.

pages.title: Verifying Newton’s Second Law of Motion (6 steps)
pages.pageTitle: Verifying Newton’s Second Law of Motion (6 steps)

typeBefore.text: Note: All measurements need to be recorded in SI units and contain the correct number of significant digits.
The following steps explain how to set up your pulley to perform Activity 2.

pageData.text: Clamp the table clamp pulley to one end of the board or table.

Use books, or similar items, to raise the pulley end of the board or table by 3 degrees from horizontal. If using the table as the incline plane, place the books under the legs of the table to adjust the angle of incline.
Use the measuring tape to measure the length of the incline, or hypotenuse, and the height of the incline, or the opposite side, as shown in Figure 4.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Triangle showing the hypotenuse, adjacent side, and opposite (incline) side with 90-degree angle

pageData.text: Using the inverse trigonometric function of sinθ, the angle can be calculated using the measurements of the length of the opposite side and the length of the hypotenuse as shown in Equation 6. Record these measurements in the Lab Notebook. Determine the angle of your incline, and record this value in Data Table 1.

pageData.altText: Equation 6: Theta equals sine sup minus 1 begin paren begin fraction length of opposite side over length of hypotenuse end fraction end paren

pageData.text: Cut a 1.5-m piece of string. Tie one end of the string around the beaker.

Place the beaker at the bottom of the incline. Extend the length of string across the pulley and down toward the floor. Tie a loop in the end of the string hanging from the pulley. The string should extend about 0.40 m down from the pulley.

typeBefore.text: Fashion a mass hanger out of a paper clip and attach it to the loop at the end of the string that will be hanging below the pulley.

pageData.text: Use the electronic balance to determine the mass of the empty plastic beaker. Record this in the Observations section.

Tie the end of the string, opposite the loop with paper clip mass hanger, around the beaker, place the beaker upside down near the bottom of the incline, extend the string over the pulley, and allow the looped end of the string with the paper clip mass hanger to hang below the pulley. Placing the beaker upside down reduces the amount of surface area that is in contact with the incline.
Using the electronic balance, determine the mass of 3 of the washers. Record this mass in Data Table 1 as the hanging mass for Trial 1.

When you add the hanging mass to the paper clip mass hanger, the beaker will move very rapidly up the incline. This is not the type of motion you want to achieve. You want the motion of the beaker to be steady and uniform so you can repeat it for additional trials. By adding mass to the beaker, you will be able to adjust the motion of the beaker.

The <button class='glossary-text'>acceleration</button> of the beaker should be approximately 2 m/s<sup class='bodySupscript'>2</sup>. At this acceleration an object would begin moving, travel between 0.50 m and 0.60 m in ~0.80 seconds, and then slow and eventually stop. The object does not continue moving because of the presence of a friction <button class='glossary-text'>force</button> opposing its motion.
Place a washer on top of the upside-down beaker. Replace the beaker at the bottom of the incline and release it.

If the beaker moves too quickly, place another washer on top of the upside-down beaker. Replace the beaker at the bottom of the incline and release it. The beaker may not move all the way up the incline; it should start moving, travel at least half the distance of the incline, slow down, and stop.

When you achieve a steady, uniform motion that you will be able to repeat, determine the amount of the moving mass. Use the electronic balance to measure the mass of the washers placed on top of the beaker. The moving mass is the total mass of the beaker plus the washers placed on top of the beaker; record this value in Data Table 1 as the moving mass for Trial 1.
Make a video recording, for inclusion in your lab report, of the beaker moving up the incline due to the tension in the string created by the weight of the 3-washer hanging mass.
pageData.altText: Record a video

pageData.text: Use the electronic balance to determine the mass of an additional washer. Add this washer to the hanging mass and record this value in Data Table 1 as the hanging mass for Trial 2.
Repeat the process of adding additional washers on top of the beaker to achieve the same steady, uniform motion achieved in Step 7.

When you achieve the same steady, uniform motion, determine the amount of the moving mass. Use the electronic balance to measure the mass of the washers placed on top of the beaker. The moving mass is the total mass of the beaker plus the washers placed on top of the beaker; record this value in Data Table 1 as the moving mass for Trial 2.
Use the electronic balance to determine the mass of an additional washer. Add this washer to the hanging mass and record this value as the hanging mass for Trial 3 in Data Table 1.
Repeat the process of adding additional washers on top of the beaker to achieve the same steady, uniform motion achieved in Step 7.

When you achieve the same steady, uniform motion, determine the amount of the moving mass. Use the electronic balance to measure the mass of the washers placed on top of the beaker. The moving mass is the total mass of the beaker plus the washers placed on top of the beaker; record this value in Data Table 1 as the moving mass for Trial 3.

Increase the angle of the incline to ~6°. Use the measuring tape to measure the length of the incline (hypotenuse) and the height of the incline (opposite side). Record these lengths in the Lab Notebook for the second angle.
Determine the angle of your incline using Equation 6, and record this value in Data Table 2.

pageData.altText: Equation 6: Theta equals sine sup minus 1 begin paren begin fraction length of opposite side over length of hypotenuse end fraction end paren

pageData.text: Reset the beaker upside down near the bottom of the incline, extend the string over the pulley, and allow the looped end of the string with the paper clip mass hanger to hang below the pulley.

Add 3 washers of known mass to the paper clip hanger; record the total mass of the washers in Data Table 2 as the hanging mass for Trial 1. If you keep track of the washers, the hanging mass will be the same as you used for Part A—First Angle.
To start, add the same number of washers, used on top of the beaker as used for Part A—First Angle, Trial 1.

Test the system to see if you get the same steady, uniform motion as you observed for Part A—First Angle. If the motion is not the same, place additional washers on top of the upside-down beaker; replace the beaker at the bottom of the incline and release it.

When you achieve the same steady, uniform motion, determine the amount of the moving mass. Use the electronic balance to measure the mass of the washers placed on top of the beaker. The moving mass is the total mass of the beaker plus the washers placed on top of the beaker; record this value in Data Table 2 as the moving mass for Trial 1.
Make a video recording, for inclusion in your lab report, of the beaker moving up the incline due to the tension in the string created by the weight of the 3-washer hanging mass.
pageData.altText: Record a video

pageData.text: Use the electronic balance to determine the mass of an additional washer. Add this washer to the hanging mass and record this value as the hanging mass for Trial 2 in Data Table 2. If you keep track of the washers, the hanging mass will be the same as you used for Part A—First Angle.
Repeat the process of adding additional washers on top of the beaker to achieve the same steady, uniform motion achieved in Step 6.

When you achieve the same steady, uniform motion, determine the amount of the moving mass. Use the electronic balance to measure the mass of the washers placed on top of the beaker. The moving mass is the total mass of the beaker plus the washers placed on top of the beaker; record this value in Data Table 2 as the moving mass for Trial 2.

Use the electronic balance to determine the mass of an additional washer. Add this washer to the hanging mass and record this value as the hanging mass for Trial 3 in Data Table 2. If you keep track of the washers, the hanging mass will be the same as you used for Part A—First Angle.
Repeat the process of adding additional washers on top of the beaker to achieve the same steady, uniform motion achieved in Step 6.

When you achieve the same steady, uniform motion, determine the amount of the moving mass. Use the electronic balance to measure the mass of the washers placed on top of the beaker. The moving mass is the total mass of the beaker plus the washers placed on top of the beaker; record this value in Data Table 2 as the moving mass for Trial 3.

Increase the angle of the incline to ~9°. Use the measuring tape to measure the length of the incline (hypotenuse) and the height of the incline (opposite side). Record these lengths in the Lab Notebook for the third angle.
Determine the angle of your incline using Equation 6, and record this value in Data Table 3.

pageData.altText: Equation 6: Theta equals sine sup minus 1 begin paren begin fraction length of opposite side over length of hypotenuse end fraction end paren

pageData.text: Reset the beaker upside down near the bottom of the incline, extend the string over the pulley, and allow the looped end of the string with the paper clip mass hanger to hang below the pulley.

Add 4 washers of known mass to the paper clip hanger; record the total mass of the washers in Data Table 3 as the hanging mass for Trial 1. If you keep track of the washers, the hanging mass will be the same 4-washer mass as you used for Trial 2 of Part A—First Angle and Part B—Second Angle.
To start, add the same number of washers used on top of the beaker for Trial 1 for Part A—First Angle and Part B—Second Angle.

Test the system to see if you get the same steady, uniform motion as you observed for Part A—First Angle and Part B—Second Angle. If the motion is not the same, place additional washers on top of the upside-down beaker; replace the beaker at the bottom of the incline and release it.

When you achieve the same steady, uniform motion, determine the amount of the moving mass. Use the electronic balance to measure the mass of the washers placed on top of the beaker. The moving mass is the total mass of the beaker plus the washers placed on top of the beaker; record this value in Data Table 3 as the moving mass for Trial 1.
Make a video recording, for inclusion in your lab report, of the beaker moving up the incline due to the tension in the string created by the weight of the 3-washer hanging mass.
pageData.altText: Record a video

pageData.text: Use the electronic balance to determine the mass of an additional washer. Add this washer to the hanging mass and record this value as the hanging mass for Trial 2 in Data Table 3. If you keep track of the washers, the hanging mass will be the same 5-washer mass as you used for the Trial 3 of Part A—First Angle and Part B—Second Angle.
Repeat the process of adding additional washers on top of the beaker to achieve the same steady, uniform motion achieved in Step 6.

When you achieve the same steady, uniform motion, determine the amount of the moving mass. Use the electronic balance to measure the mass of the washers placed on top of the beaker. The moving mass is the total mass of the beaker plus the washers placed on top of the beaker; record this value in Data Table 3 as the moving mass for Trial 2.

Use the electronic balance to determine the mass of an additional washer. Add this washer to the hanging mass and record this as the hanging mass for Trial 3 in Data Table 3. (Your hanging mass for Trial 3 will be 6 washers.)
Repeat the process of adding additional washers on top of the beaker to achieve the same steady, uniform motion achieved in Step 6.

When you achieve the same steady, uniform motion, determine the amount of the moving mass. Use the electronic balance to measure the mass of the washers placed on top of the beaker. The moving mass is the total mass of the beaker plus the washers placed on top of the beaker; record this value in Data Table 3 as the moving mass for the Trial 3.
Using Equation 5, calculate the acceleration for each trial in Data Tables 1, 2, and 3 of the two-mass system on an incline. Record these acceleration values in Data Tables 1, 2, and 3, respectively.

pageData.altText: Equation 5: a equals begin fraction g begin paren m sub 2 minus sign m sub 1 sine theta end paren over begin paren m sub 1 plus m sub 2 end paren end fraction

pageData.text: Calculate mean (average) acceleration ā [m/s2] and the standard deviation, σ , (Equation 7) for the data in Data Tables 1, 2, and 3. Record these values in Data Table 4.

pageData.altText: Equation 7: Lowercase sigma equals begin square root begin fraction capital sigma sup n sub I equals 1 begin paren a sub I minus mean a close paren squared over n minus 1 end fraction end square root.

pageData.text:
whereσ = standard deviation
n = the number of data points
ai = the value of acceleration from the trial
ā = mean acceleration

Determination of standard deviation requires repeated calculations that require substituting each value of the sample into the same formula.  For a small sample size, n, this can be done manually; however, for larger samples the calculation can be done in a spreadsheet program such as Excel or Google sheets.  The function, STDEV, is used to determine the standard deviation of a sample.  Refer to the spreadsheet program help and support centers for details on how to configure the STDEV function.

In distributions of data, about 95% of values will be within 2 standard deviations of the mean. Values that are within ±2 standard deviations of the mean represent measurements that are considered to be near the true value. Review the data from the investigation and determine whether your calculated accelerations are within ±2 standard deviations. Report, using numerical values, whether your data for each angle is within ±2 standard deviations. Data Table 5 will help you evaluate your data.

pageData.title: Newton’s Laws of Motion Demonstrated Using a Balloon Rocket
pageData.text: In the Extension Activity, you will create balloon rockets that move along a string. You will then compare the distance travelled along the string by a full and a half-full balloon rocket.

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Observe action and reaction <button class='glossary-text'>forces</button> using a balloon traveling along a string.
Compare the distances a balloon travels on string when filled with different amounts of air.

pageData.title: Background
pageData.text: A rocket’s movement depends on <button class='glossary-text'>Newton’s third law of motion</button>, which states for every action there is an equal and opposite reaction. When a rocket blows out gas at high speed in one direction (action force), the rocket is pushed in the opposite direction (reaction force). When there is a force on an object in one direction, another force is acting on the other object in the opposite direction. The gas pushes against the rocket, and the rocket pushes back just as hard against the gas.

In the extension activity, a rocket will be simulated using a balloon on a string. The balloon will be attached to a drinking straw that has been strung through a long length of string allowing the attached balloon to travel along the string. The balloon will be filled with air that will be allowed to escape, propelling the balloon forward.

text: 1–6 Balloons of the same size and shape (You can perform the activity with 1 balloon, but it is a good idea to have extra balloons available in case it breaks.)
String from the materials kit, 15–16 feet (or less depending on the space you have available to set up the balloon rocket)
2 Chairs with upright backs of the same height
Scissors
Measuring tape from the materials kit
Transparent tape
Drinking straw
Pen or marker
Cell phone or comparable mobile device for taking video and pictures
Optional but recommended: a volunteer to assist you in releasing the balloon or taking video of the balloon rocket

pageData.text: Locate an area with a long space free of obstructions, such as a hallway. If possible, locate a space where you can place the 2 chairs approximately 5 to 6 m (16–20 feet) apart. If not, locate the longest space you have available.
Place the chairs at opposite ends of the space, backs of the chairs facing each other.
Measure out enough string to go the length of the space between the backs of the chairs plus some additional string for tying the ends of the string to the chairs.
Before tying the string to the backs of the chairs, place the straw on the string.
Tie each end of the string to the back of a chair. Tighten the string so there is no slack in the string.
Pull the straw up to the back of one of the chairs. Mark the starting position of the straw with a pen or marker. Mark the end of the straw closest to the back of the chair.

Blow up a balloon full of air. Completely fill the balloon but do not over fill it. To fill the balloon to the same level for each trial, use the measuring tape to determine the circumference of the balloon at the largest section. Note this measurement, and fill the balloon to the same circumference for each trial.
Hold the end of the balloon closed but do not tie it. Attach the balloon underneath the straw with a piece of transparent tape, as shown in Figure 5.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Person holding a blue balloon that is attached to a drinking straw with transparent tape that is attached to a white piece of string

pageData.text: Start recording a video, and then release your hold on the balloon.
pageData.altText: Record a video

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>force</button> of the air being propelled out of the balloon will force it along the string. After the balloon stops, you can stop recording.

Measure how far from its starting position the balloon traveled. Measure from the mark made near the back of the chair to the location where the same end of the straw stopped. Record this measurement in Data Table E1 for Trial 1.

Carefully remove the balloon from the straw; pull the straw back to the starting position. Ensure the string is still tight, and repeat Steps 7–11 (you do not need to video each trial) for Trial 2 with a full balloon. If your balloon breaks, replace it with a new one.

Carefully remove the balloon from the straw; pull the straw back to the starting position. Ensure the string is still tight, and repeat Steps 7–11 (you do not need to video each trial) for Trial 3 with for a full balloon. If your balloon breaks, replace it with a new one.

Review the measurements you made for the 3 trials for consistency. It may be difficult to get identical conditions for each trial, as the balloon’s flight may vary. You should have measurements that are not significantly different. Repeat trials if needed to get consistent data.
Carefully remove the balloon from the straw; pull the straw back to the starting position. Ensure the string is still tight. If your balloon breaks, replace it with a new one.

Determine the radius and circumference of a half-full balloon. The volume of a sphere is (4/3)πr3 so if the radius is halved, the volume is reduced to one-eighth the original volume. For half the volume, the radius of the balloon should be reduced by approximately 20% or be about 0.8 times the radius of the full balloon. Using this information, determine the circumference of a half-full balloon.

Blow up the balloon so it is half full of air; use the measuring tape to determine the circumference of the balloon at the largest section and adjust the volume of air until you have the circumference of a half-full balloon.
Hold the end of the balloon closed but do not tie it. Attach the balloon underneath the straw with a piece of transparent tape.
Begin recording your video, then release your hold on the balloon.
pageData.altText: Record a video

pageData.text: The force of the air being propelled out of the balloon will force it along the string. After the balloon stops you can stop recording.

Measure how far from its starting position the balloon traveled. Measure from the mark made near the back of the chair to the location where the same end of the straw stopped. Record this measurement in Data Table E2 for Trial 1.

Carefully remove the balloon from the straw; pull the straw back to the starting position. Ensure the string is still tight, and repeat Steps 3 through 7 (you do not need to video each trial) for Trial 2 for a half-full balloon.

Carefully remove the balloon from the straw; pull the straw back to the starting position. Ensure the string is still tight, and repeat Steps 3 through 7 (you do not need to video each trial) for Trial 3 for a half-full balloon.

Review the measurements you made for the 3 trials for consistency. It may be difficult to get identical conditions for each trial, but you should have measurements that are not widely varied. Repeat trials if needed to get consistent data.
Clean your work space.
Return the materials to the equipment kit, and clean the area.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

pageData.altText: Equation 1: Epsilon F equals ma or F equals begin fraction dp over dt end fraction

pageData.content: Equation 2. Newton’s law of universal gravitation
pageData.altText: Equation 2: F equals begin fraction G m sub 1 m sub 2 over r sub 2 end fraction where G equals 6.67 times 10 sup minus sign 11 begin fraction m sup 3 over kg s sup 2 end fraction

pageData.altText: Equation 3: Epsilon p sub before equals epsilon p sub after

pageData.content: Equation 5. Acceleration of a mass on an incline with a pulley

A map of the procedural workflow of activities 1-2 of the investigation. In activity 1, set up an index card, beaker and coin and record the removal of the index card and fall of the coin. Next, add another coin and repeat. Then, fill a beaker, place it on a paper at the edge of a table and record the removal of the paper. Then, repeat with an empty beaker.  In activity 2, set up the ramp and pulley and calculate its angle and dimensions. Then, set up the beaker with string and attach it to the pulley. Next, measure the mass of the beaker and washers. Then, attach washers to the hanger. Next, add washers to the beaker until it is moving with an acceleration of ~2 m/s2. Then, measure the total mass of the washers in the beaker and repeat for 3 trials. Next, modify the angle of the ramp and repeat for 3 angles. Then, calculate the acceleration for each trial, the average acceleration and the standard deviation. Finally, analyze the data for a standard distribution. Proceed to the extension activity.

A map of the procedural workflow of the extension activity of this investigation. After completing activity 2, in the extension activity, you will fully inflate a balloon and attach a straw to it. Then, you will set up the string, balloon apparatus and chairs. Next, you will measure the circumference of the inflated balloon. Then, you will record the release and flight of the balloon along the sting and measure the distance of the flight. When you have completed 3 trials for the fully inflated balloon, you will then inflate the balloon half-full and attach a straw to it. Then, you will set up the string, balloon apparatus and chairs. Next, you will measure the circumference of the inflated balloon. Then, you will record the release and flight of the balloon along the sting and measure the distance of the flight. Finally, you will repeat this for 3 trials.
Figure 4: Triangle showing the hypotenuse, adjacent side, and opposite (incline) side with 90-degree angle

data.title: Acceleration
data.content: The change in velocity with respect to time

data.title: Bernoulli's principle
data.content: Describes the conservation of energy for fluid flow; the total energy per unit mass of flowing fluid is the sum of the kinetic, potential and fluid pressure energies, and their sum is equal to a constant

data.title: Classical mechanics
data.content: The area of physics built on works of Sir Isaac Newton comprised of Newton's three laws of motion and Newton's law of universal gravitation

data.title: Force
data.content: A push or pull of an object with mass that causes it to accelerate if unopposed

data.title: Free body diagram
data.content: A graphical illustration used to identify the forces acting on an object

data.title: Inertia
data.content: The tendency of an object to resist changes in motion

data.title: Law of conservation of energy
data.content: States that energy cannot be created or destroyed, it can only transform from one type to another

data.title: Law of conservation of momentum
data.content: States that for an isolated system where there is no external force, the total momentum before a collision is equal to the total momentum after the collision

data.title: Law of inertia
data.content: See Newton's first law of motion

data.title: Momentum
data.content: The quantity of motion of a moving body; it is measured as a product of its mass and velocity

data.title: Newton's first law of motion
data.content: States that an object at rest remains at rest and an object in motion remains in motion at constant speed unless acted upon by unbalanced forces; also called the law of inertia

data.title: Newton's law of universal gravitation
data.content: States that every particle attracts every other particle in the universe with a force directly proportional to the product of the masses, and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them

data.title: Newton's second law of motion
data.content: States that the net force is equal to mass times acceleration

data.title: Newton's third law of motion
data.content: States that for every action force, there is an equal and opposite reaction force
